items.title: Environmental damage is putting European way of life at risk, says report
items.content_html:
EU officials warn climate breakdown and wildlife loss ‚Äòare ruining ecosystems that underpin the economy‚Äô

The European way of life is being jeopardised by environmental degradation, a report has found, with EU officials warning against weakening green rules.

The continent has made ‚Äúimportant progress‚Äù in cutting planet-heating pollution, according to the European Environment Agency, but the death of wildlife and breakdown of the climate are ruining ecosystems that underpin the economy.

More than 80% of protected habitats are in a poor or bad state, with ‚Äúunsustainable‚Äù consumption and production patterns driving loss of wildlife.

The EU‚Äôs ‚Äúcarbon sink‚Äù has declined by about 30% in a decade as logging, wildfires and pests damage forests.

Emissions from transport and food have barely budged since 2005, despite progress in other sectors.

Member states have failed to adapt to extreme weather as fast as risk levels have risen.

Water stress already affects one in three Europeans and will worsen as the climate changes.

Continue reading...

Zimbabwean writer NoViolet Bulawayo has won the Best of Caine award, an honorary prize celebrating a story from past winners of the Caine Prize for African Writing, to mark its 25th anniversary. The prize was given for a short story praised by judges for its ‚Äúpowerful language, distinctive tone of voice, and bold, compelling storytelling‚Äù.

Hitting Budapest, which won the 2011 Caine prize, follows a group of six children who sneak from their shantytown, Paradise, into an affluent neighbourhood, Budapest, to steal guavas. First published in the Boston Review, it examines poverty, social and economic inequalities, and the dreams of children.

The newfound camaraderie between the US and Pakistan was on full display this week as Donald Trump welcomed Pakistan‚Äôs prime minister, Shehbaz Sharif, and the country‚Äôs powerful army chief, Asim Munir, into the Oval Office, heralding them both as ‚Äúgreat leaders‚Äù.

items.title: ‚ÄòA donkey cart out of El Fasher costs more than a new car‚Äô: how 500 days under siege is tearing the city apart

Special report: ‚ÄòWe will never, ever escape‚Äô: inside the ever-tightening siege of the Sudanese city of El Fasher

For 17 months, since May 2024, El Fasher, North Darfur‚Äôs capital, has been trapped in one of the longest urban sieges of modern warfare, a slow war of attrition that recalls the destruction of Stalingrad and the starvation of Leningrad, combining both cruelties in a single city.

The siege, progressively tightened by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), has transformed the city. Trenches cut through neighbourhoods. Civilians move block by block in search of safety, while self-defence groups fight alongside entrenched garrisons.

items.title: Blood Moon: What makes a total lunar eclipse

items.title: Bundesliga: Can expanded league help competition?
items.content_html: The Women's Bundesliga has expanded to 14 clubs this season but in the last 12 years only two sides have been in contention for the title. While women's football in Germany is growing, it still lags behind the UK and US.

items.content_html: As the International Mobility Show opens in Munich, the German car industry is facing roadblocks on many sides. That's why manufactures are polishing up to prove they are ready to conquer the future of modern mobility.

items.title: Fires in Spain and Portugal fueled by climate change
items.content_html: Wildfires caused devastation in Spain and Portugal this summer. Scientists say that rising global temperatures caused by burning fossil fuels has made the deadly fires 40 times more likely.

items.title: Desalination doesn't have to be bad for the environment
items.content_html: Drinking from the sea is essential to securing water supply but often has negative environmental impacts. Scientists say they can be minimized with careful planning and process.

items.title: Landslides and mudslides: Why they happen
items.content_html: Non-stop rain in Sudan caused a landslide to cover an entire village. The science of these natural disasters is simple. Preventing them is possible.

items.title: How humans made chickens grow and foxes shrink
items.content_html: Archeologists in southern France have studied bones spanning 8,000 years to reveal how humans caused domestic animals to grow in overall size, while wild animals shrank.

items.title: Digital taxes put US-EU trade talks under pressure

items.title: Sex testing in athletics a setback to science?
items.content_html: Former Spanish hurdler Maria Jose Martinez-Patino knows better than most about genetic testing, having missed out on a chance at the Olympics as a result of it. She spoke to DW about World Athletics' new regulations.

items.title: Bundesliga: Leverkusen sack coach ten Hag after two games

items.title: Germany's road to 2026 World Cup begins: What to know
